positive.review: Ubisoft really said "Let's make a viking game, give the main character the hidden blade, and call it assassins creed

Look, Spoiled America loves to find reasons to hate things, but honestly, there's almost nothing to complain about here.

Sure, it crashes sometimes, and yeah, there are some weird, wonky glitches. My Asgard mount looked warped once, and some NPCs reset awkwardly after events. Big deal. I've had way worse experiences.

If you like Assassin's Creed, you're going to like this. Period.

The weapons and variations are fun. I love the classic sneak attacks from bushes and rooftops, and the general combat flow is solid. It feels like an Odyssey and Skyrim hybrid, just minus the dragons. The ability tree is amazing; you can be a Viking brute, an archer, or a sneaky assassin. Tons of play styles to mix up.

The extra modes are what really push this game over the top. They are seriously cool and not just throwaways:

Raiding: Get your adrenaline fix. Gathering the crew, sailing, and crashing a monastery for loot is brutal and satisfying as hel.

Settlement Building: Watching your base, Ravensthorpe, grow from a dump into a proper home is genuinely rewarding. It’s the heart of the game and makes coming back feel important.

Asgard Questline: Playing as Havi (Odin) in Asgard is wild. It’s this massive, gorgeous fantasy side-game that fits perfectly.

Niflheim (The Forgotten Saga): Love the roguelite mode. It's a quick, high-stakes blast through the realm of the dead. Great for keeping the combat skills sharp.

Just buy it when it's on sale. Be frugal. Less to complain about if you don't pay full price.

People usually complain about this game being so long and so repetitive, they complain about it not feeling like an Assassin's Creed... I get it, it is ABSOLUTELY LONG, and NOT AN ASSASIN'S CREED experience that you would expect. 

BUT - It has absolutely stunning graphics, a huge map that feels so alive and yet full of solitude at the same time. ABSOLUTE BEAUTY! And about being repetitive, every other game is repetitive to some extent. This one may feel repetitive in terms of mechanisms, looting and fights you have to go through, but all the locations are very different. Locations like Cavern of Trials etc. are so fascinating! 

And yes, it's NOT A GOOD ASSASIN'S CREED experience, I accept it. But it doesn't mean it's bad as a game. It gives off those Norse vibes with a load of awe-inspiring myths and legends. Boss Fights feel like an easy Souls Game, but that's relaxing! 

I just love this game! Everyone who wants to live as a Viking & as a Norse god (If you get the DLCs too), this is the perfect game, believe me!

It makes sense that there would've been assassins even during the viking-period (since assassins have always been active), and it would be weird if a VIKING would become a full assassin. So the way the story went is very well done (option to go full a-viking but also able to sneak and assassinate). 
Besides that, I really enjoy the RPG aspect. It can feel one-toned from time to time, but there is plenty to do to help with that. Also Dag and Sigurd should both take a chill pill.

Moral of the story, it's not your typical AC game, but great soft RPG game to keep up with the lore!

EDIT: I have previously not recommended the game due to frequent crashes. From what I could gather, the problem stands in how the frames are displayed and it can crash the driver no matter if you are using nvidia or amd. However, I managed to get rid of the problem by maxing out the graphics settings, removing the upscalling, setting the fps limiter to 60 on a 120hz display and the v sync to adaptive (even though I have free sync active). I have managed to get a good few hours in without any more crashes. Even if it would still happen once in a blue moon, having about 5 hours without a crash is good enough for me. If not possible to play without upscaling or to max our graphics, I would still try to limit fps and enable v sync (adaptive if using g sync or freesync). I do not know exactly what fixed it, but this is what I've done and I hope it helps you if facing similar issues.

The playing cycle and the stories are goodish. I am not particularly interested in the Norse mythology like I was in the Greek one, but it is nevertheless an interesting take on the gods, albeit it lacks soul a bit and it feels mundane at times. It's not truly inspiring, but it serves the purpose of creating a context for the game. The arc stories however are quite good, nothing out of the ordinary, but they are fun to play for the most part.

The fighting feels lively and I enjoy it. I don't know how it would feel on the higher difficulties because I have no interest in being frustrated, but on lower ones it feels like AC with parrying and dodging playing a big role as well as a lot of improvements and great cinematic finishers. I don't think you can totally dislike the combat, it feels complete, polished and has me coming back.

The raids as well as the sieges feels great and exciting. The mechanics are satisfying and after you begin to understand the basic ways of getting into buildings it feel rewarding as well. It's a great mechanic and I think a great majority of people will enjoy it.

Not finished the game yet. But I can definitely see the complaints and the praises of this game.

The combat is very solid but lacks some more variety kill animations. This is solved via the abundance of weapons, but it is more of a personal gripe. Perfect Parry is the best perk for combat hands down.

The stealth is... okay? Surprisingly decent and it is much easier to spec into assassination damage than previous titles. Although, you need a perk that allows you to do a QTE to assassinate more challenging enemies. The bow is also pretty darn good when doing stealth.

I also see why people say the story drags on a lot. Big event happens, cliffhanger and then "Another settlement needs your help" type thing with forging alliances. Breaks the pacing of the game heavily.

Stability wise, I have a pretty decent PC and the game runs very smooth with next to no frame drops. But... it has randomly crashed 6 or 7 times in the past 2 weeks for what feels like random reasons. It especially sucks when the game crashes after a raid and then I have to redo it.

Overall at the current time, I'd probably give the game a 6/10 so far maybe 6.5/10. It is better than average and I'd say it is a 'good' game. Just not a 'great game' or an 'amazing game'.

[h1] PROS: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Panoramic Views, the world is absolutely breathtaking
    [*] The visuals are gorgeous, and the photo mode lets you capture jaw-dropping moments worthy of wallpapers.
    [*] Whether you’re charging in like a fierce Viking warrior or sneaking through shadows, combat feels powerful and satisfying.
    [*] There’s a huge variety of weapons, armor sets, and abilities to experiment with — perfect for customizing your play style.
    [*] You can pet cats and dogs.
    [*] There’s always something new to discover — hidden caves, treasures, and secrets scattered across vast landscapes.
    [*] Raids feel awesome when you slaughter 10 enemies at once etc. 
    [*] The narrative blends Norse mythology and historical intrigue beautifully.
    [*] Interesting DLCS.
[/list]

[h1] CONS: [/h1]
[list]
    [*] Some laggy/shaky graphics.
    [*] Raven controls were terrible until I figure them out.
    [*] Some random bugs/game crashes.
    [*] You can climb almost anything… except that one wall Eivor randomly refuses to scale.
    [*] The stone game (Orlog) can be painful with poor camera angles and clunky controls.
    [*] WHY SO F MANY TREASURE/ARTIFACTS TO COLLECT!!?!??!?! So much grind!
    [*] Tomb of the Fallens have hidden artifacts in them, and if you miss them you can't fast travel.
    [*] Some mastery challenges have terrible design.
    [*] Brace yourself if you plan to do 100%.
[/list]

[h1] OVERALL: [/h1]
Assassin’s Creed Valhalla is an epic, immersive adventure that brilliantly captures the spirit of the Viking age. The world is vast and gorgeous, offering hours upon hours of exploration, combat, and storytelling. The mix of brutal raids, mythological elements, and deep customization makes it one of the most ambitious entries in the franchise.

That said, it’s not without flaws — technical hiccups, clunky mechanics, and an overload of collectibles can test your patience. But if you’re a fan of open-world RPGs and love Norse mythology, this game is absolutely worth diving into.

Completing only for the sake completing. The story seems promising and that's what keeps me going but I cannot recommend this to anyone because the gameplay is torture. This game was not made with passion and it shows. The map is large, pretty and soulless.

When you're not playing the story the gameplay goes like this - Ride a horse for 2 minutes, swim for a minute across a river(your horse can swim while you are on it), ride horse for another 2 minutes, reach the point of interest on the map, find out that it's a chest or an artifact or a book of knowledge or whatever and that it's behind a stone wall that you need to blow up with an oil jar. Go look for an oil jar. Pick it up, jog towards the stone wall because you can't sprint with that weight on your shoulders. Now blow up the stone wall, enter the cave, duck under obstacles, jump over obstacles, trigger a cutscene of slipping through a crevice, finally collect what you came for.

That was extremely boring TO JUST READ, right? Imagine how boring it is to play it.

All of this takes about 10-15 mins. And there are HUNDREDS of such locations, not exaggerating the number. Literally hundreds. They give next to no rewards for all the hoops you jump through. And when they do, they're useless, you won't even use that stuff. They added a feature where your horse swims with you on its back and that says enough about how boring the map is and what a drag it is just to get from point A to point B and even the devs couldn't bear to keep switching modes of travel for pointless objectives.

There are cutscenes where the NPCs refer to your character as she/her, even when you play as a male.  Also, sometimes male eivor grunts in the female Eivor's voice. They didn't take the effort to dub some lines for both genders.

[h1]Assassin’s Creed Valhalla Review[/h1]

[hr]
[h1]Overview[/h1]
Big, pretty, and stuffed to the brim. I ended up 100%ing it across Epic and Steam, saves carried over, achievements and all. Treat it like a giant Viking RPG and you will have a good time. Treat it like classic Assassin’s Creed and you will wonder where the hidden blades went.

[hr]
[h1]How I Got Sucked In[/h1]
I bought it on Epic, then again on Steam when it landed there. Seeing my saves carry over made my brain go, “well, now you have to finish it.” I was on a Ubisoft achievements binge, so Valhalla became The Big One. Hours later… okay, hundreds of hours later… the checklist brain was fed.

[hr]
[h1]World and Performance[/h1]
No debate here: the world is gorgeous. England’s rolling fields, snowy Norway, trippy Asgard, and the DLC zones all look great. Just wandering is half the appeal, especially early on when every hill has a postcard view. Performance was rock solid for me on high settings. Points for optimization.

[hr]
[h1]Story and Vibe[/h1]
I like Eivor and I liked the overall journey, but it is long. Near the end I felt the “let’s wrap this up” itch. As an Assassin’s Creed game, it barely whispers; as a Viking epic, it sings. If you walk in expecting social stealth and concise plotting, you will bounce. Walk in expecting mead, raids, and myth, and it works much better.

[hr]
[h1]Combat and Systems[/h1]
Fun toolkit, a bunch of flashy abilities, solid hits. After dozens of hours the repetition creeps in because the game is enormous. Raids start as a party and slowly turn into meal prep. Collectibles are everywhere. If you are chasing 100%, prepare for a relationship with your map filter.

[hr]
[h1]Length, Patience, Sanity[/h1]
My Steam time shows ~70 hours, but my carryover save pushes past 300. This is a marathon. Take breaks. Touch grass. Come back. Repeat. Valhalla rewards the slow-burn approach way more than the “I will finish this in a weekend” approach. Your thumbs will thank you.

[hr]
[h1]DLCs[/h1]
Dawn of Ragnarök is my favorite. New abilities, fun setting, cool characters. Yes, I know some people disliked it; I vibed with it. It is also not in the season pass and costs extra, which stings. There is also a roguelike mode for people who looked at a 200+ hour RPG and said, “needs more grind.”

[hr]
[h1]Exploration, Collectibles, Achievements[/h1]
Exploration is inviting and genuinely rewarding at first, then the scale hits you. The number of shiny things is… generous. Achievements are doable but grindy across the base map, Asgard, and DLC areas. If you love filling bars and hearing little chimes, you will be very, very happy.

[hr]
[h1]Mindset Matters[/h1]
The magic trick is simple: stop calling it Assassin’s Creed in your head. Call it Viking Life Simulator with parkour. Suddenly the expectations line up and you start enjoying the parts it actually nails.

[hr]
[h1]Who Will Like It[/h1]

Explorers who want a massive world to roam at a relaxed pace

Power fantasy enjoyers who like abilities, loot, and long arcs

Achievement hunters who live for a big checklist and do not fear spreadsheets

[hr]
[h1]Who Will Not[/h1]

Stealth-first AC purists wanting tight, focused missions

Players allergic to collectible bloat and 100-hour plus commitments

Anyone who wants their DLCs included in one tidy pass

[hr]
[h1]Verdict[/h1]
Recommended on sale, especially if “Viking open world RPG” sounds comfy. The visuals and performance are great, the journey has highlights, and Dawn of Ragnarök was a win for me. It is bloated, yes, and the Assassin part of the creed took a sabbatical, but with the right mindset and some well-timed breaks, Valhalla delivers a meaty adventure worth sinking an axe into.

🔰SHREDVIEW🔰 - From someone who actually plays and finishes the games before reviewing.

NOTE: If you like my work, please check out the rest of my reviews, I put a lot of work in these to offer the best overall description of what you’re up against. Thank you in advance!

🔷 ABOUT THE GAME & LORE 🔷

Meet Eivor, a Viking raider leading their clan from Norway to settle in England during the 9th century. The story blends Norse mythology with Ubisoft’s long-running Assassin–Templar gig. At its heart it’s about conquest, alliances, and carving out a legacy. I actually liked the story a lot here despite popular opinion, it was engaging enough, even if it didn’t reinvent the formula. I’m a mythology enthusiast, quite a lot actually so for me it paid off to see these characters in any sort of scenario and have control over them to immerse into the world. 

But let’s not kid ourselves, this is the same pattern Ubisoft already used in Origins and Odyssey. It’s basically the same game but dressed up with Vikings. What makes it feel different are the weapons, combat mechanics, and a Norse skill tree that gives the fights some unique flavor.

🔷 THE GAMEPLAY 🔷

👉 GENERAL:
The core loop is exactly what you’d expect. Explore, raid, loot, upgrade your settlement, and cut through armies with axes, swords, and bows. It’s fun in bursts but bloated as hell, padded with filler until you start asking when it will finally end. Ubisoft copy-pasted their formula until it bled.

    •	The game carries itself in a decent manner along with the story, if you really like Norse mythology, it will satisfy that itch. It’s also easy to master and learn your way around it, I think they did a good job on being user-friendly but that’s ok, it was enough good for the people cause they f***d up almost everything else.   

    •	Combat works well enough, and I liked how different weapon types and dual-wielding felt. Some of the bigger weapons bug out and s**t and parrying mech isn’t always reliable either. Works and feels more than Batman Arkham Asylum or old AC one button mashing but they didn’t change from the past 2 titles on this engine. 

    •	As Ubisoft s**tfaced tradition demands, the game is full of mini-glitches: grabbing onto nothing, getting stuck on barrels, random climbing on tiny objects, awkward AI pathing, parries not registering, falling into the ground head down while running animation plays and can’t do anything but reload (this s**t looked funny), enemies spinning in circles, AI being giga-dumb, and the list goes on.  

    •	Exploration is rewarding, guys! There’s always the same less than 10 loot types to uncover from a million locations on the map. The game is dragging quests and arcs far beyond where they should end. Skyrim gave me content worth staying for and taught me to enjoy long games but Valhalla gave me repetition that made me beg for the credits, rabies and an invoice for another keyboard. 

    •	The infamous trailing missions just can’t miss from anything ass creed. Follow X for 15 minutes straight while they walk as slow as the game engine allows them to. I’m lost for words. F**k this s**t until it goes flat. God d**n man!

    •	To work at Ubisoft you need 2 major skills. To know how to press CTRL + C and how to press CTRL + V. Origins was Ubisoft's first time in a long run when they waited 2 years before releasing a game and spared us the yearly effortless feces. Then they decided it was enough and kept on using the same engine and pattern of core gameplay for a million of more games: Odyssey, Valhalla, Mirage, that disrespectful piece of trash wannabe Japanese and wait for the next!

    •	Great voice actor for Eivor and Odin! Other good actors too. The voice acting wasn't generally bad, what makes it shit is because characters have unnatural and awkward face expressions, movements and reactions during segments.

👉 NAVIGATION SYSTEM
Ehh… You run, you dash, you climb, you parkour with Michael Scott, you kill enemies, do quests, do side quests, what you did in any AC game. You have a map, map works, map is full of stuff to do until you figure out it’s the same stuff to do all over the place. That enough? Nothing special here, it’s at least user friendly, you can master navigation very easily and enjoy it for a good while.  

👉 PHYSICS & MECHANICS 
Combat animations have weight, stealth is serviceable at most and progression is steady. The problem is reliability. Parry input can fail, enemies bug out, and certain weapon interactions feel off. Nothing game-breaking, just death by a thousand cuts that wear you down across 200+ hours. 

👉  GRAPHICS & OPTIMIZATION 
Beautiful world. No, I don’t need Wukong graphics here so it does the job in my book. England looks gorgeous, lighting sells the mood, and the engine does its job. Performance was smooth all the way. I find the video-cutscenes being ass quality compared to the game itself, I don't know how they manage but the cutscenes, while being very few, they look like crap. 

👉  ACHIEVEMENTS & COLLECTIBLES 
Achievements... oh boy, see this game? Number 1 bulls**t game. The achievements in this game are so t*rded that I wore a diaper for the entire playthrough because of shitting on them achievements constantly. I don't even know where to start... They are all do'able but the amount of time they take is  insane. F**k Ubisoft and f**k this game even if it's decent. If you're a completionist, do not engage! 
Never will I play another AC game, I'm done, what the hell was this bro?! Guess what, they are tied to paid DLC, this practice is straight giggidy the f**k ass s**t. 

🔷  CONCLUSION  🔷

This is a decent game but it is also a very annoying game. The story is good, the combat is fine-ish, the world is beautiful, the performance is beautiful and my noodle is large. The problem is it’s also bloated with repetetitive, copy pasted, glitchy, amateurish small bugs, they pile up into a tower of lost braincells. If you don’t care about 100% completion, you can enjoy it for the Viking fantasy it delivers. If you are a completionist, avoid it like the plague

Go look for an oil jar. Pick it up, jog towards the stone wall because you can't sprint with that weight on your shoulders. Now blow up the stone wall, enter the cave, duck under obstacles, jump over obstacles, trigger a cutscene of slipping through a crevice, finally collect what you came for.

That was extremely boring TO JUST READ, right? Imagine how boring it is to play it.

They added a feature where your horse swims with you on its back and that says enough about how boring the map is and what a drag it is just to get from point A to point B and even the devs couldn't bear to keep switching modes of travel for pointless objectives.

Valhalla is gorgeous but shallow. Its campaign sprawls for dozens of hours without a compelling throughline; regional arcs feel disconnected and rarely build toward anything meaningful, so the story often comes off as aimless rather than epic. The result is a lot of time investment for little narrative payoff.

Moment-to-moment design leans heavily on repetition. Side activities and puzzles recycle the same beats, padding the runtime instead of deepening the world. The map is vast and pretty, yet frequently feels empty—large stretches of space with limited reasons to engage beyond checklist cleanup.

Systems don’t rescue it. Stealth and combat suffer from erratic, easily exploited AI that oscillates between unresponsive and omniscient, making encounters feel cheap rather than challenging.

Technical polish is inconsistent. Crashes, visual/audio glitches, and long load times at and after launch...

A beautiful but empty world, thin writing, weak AI, and persistent bugs make Valhalla feel like a lavish production with little depth where it matters.

Decided to work my way through the Assassin's creed franchise. Finally got to this one, then I uninstalled the game after a few hours. It's the worst I have come across so far. So much potential, just fell very short in the execution. Camera angles are buggy, you often have a building or hut obscuring your view entirely. You no longer highlight enemies with your vision sense, just heat maps those nearby. Combat is boring, no more counters, dodge doesn't reward or even dodge attacks (you just move out of range). Using a controller with a bad R bumper was a hassle, they don't have build in alternate like (button puncher, or alternate mapping) you have to program everything and it often is a mess trying not to map over other features. In combat you just mash light attack as often as you can. Until you meet a templar, then it's zero damage. That's right, not just a big challenge, they decided to make it impossible. No hits will damage or even land on high level templars. The boat and horse are a mess with the route following, they constantly are headed in a direction, you choose to follow and they will turn completely around, which is odd considering there is no go to obective any longer, just buggy. The sequence to start following route is a longer process so by the time you fix it you are in the shoreline struggling to paddle backwards to fix the bug. There is not a very clear line between being hidden or being in combat, the two come in and out constantly for no reason. High level archer characters can see you even hidden from almost a mile away at times, you have a danger indicator sitting on you for minutes until a random arrow gets lucky enough to one shot you from across the map and you have to start the raid you put an hour into all over again for the 5th time. Had enough, Seemed like it could have been a cool entry, nice graphics, decent plot, they must have rushed this one out. I'd recommend skipping this chapter.

Listing everything wrong with the game would fill an entire book.
This game is a huge step back from Odyssey and a veritable mess of bugs and crashes.

The good:
There is an ability that allows your raven to pick up loot from enemies killed with a bow.

The bad:
The world is empty and dead.
Almost all the locations look like something out of Dark Souls (dead and ugly).
Some sound effects don't fit the game, like collecting the masks. It sounds like a creature from a horror game is hiding around the next corner.
Unsympathetic characters.
Far too many collectibles.

No more loot from enemies.
New gear is extremely rare, only 1 per special chest (use a guide to get a good set and be prepared to use it throughout the game, the same goes for weapons).
Or you can use your credit card and buy new gear from the cash shop (no skins!).

The gold medal challenges are almost completely broken, for example, enemies simply climb out of the level.
Some bosses are broken and require many tries and luck, such as the Fenris Wolf boss fight (it keeps getting stuck in the ground).
If you use a non-horse mount and go to Asgard (the dream world), you'll get a glitch mount, like something out of nightmares (legs twisted upwards and textures stretched toward the sky).
These bugs have been known for years but aren't fixed.

Almost all chests (only one at a time) are located behind a locked wooden door.
Your Viking can't break down the door with his axe. Instead, you can walk around the houses looking for holes or breakable parts to crawl into (you only have to do this a few hundred times; some have puzzles and hidden entrances on top).
Not all underground entrances are shown on the map.

Your bird is now worth less than a chicken nugget and can't even mark enemies anymore.
The kill animations are too long and are 100% triggered by melee attacks on elite enemies (and these are very common enemies). They can't be skipped or deactivated (elite enemies are best killed with bows only).
And much, much, much more.

For 100%: Don't do it.
It takes over 200 hours with guides and is very dependent on luck with the bugs and crashes.
Remember that to get 100%, you have to earn gold medals in the challenges. These have a fixed maximum difficulty, gear, and abilities, and are riddled with bugs. One of the DLCs is a separate rouge-like mode with maximum difficulty that has nothing in common with the base game.
